description:
Phaeoacremonium minimum UCRPA7 is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Phaeoacremonium. This genus is classified within the family Togniniaceae, order Togniniales, and class Sordariomycetes.

Phaeoacremonium minimum is a dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungus known to be associated with grapevine trunk diseases, particularly Petri disease and esca. It is considered an opportunistic pathogen that can infect the woody tissues of grapevines, leading to the development of various symptoms, such as vascular discoloration, stunted growth, and dieback.

The strain UCRPA7 is a specific isolate of Phaeoacremonium minimum that has been studied and characterized. This strain may exhibit particular morphological, physiological, or genetic characteristics that differentiate it from other isolates within the species.

Further research on the biology, epidemiology, and host-pathogen interactions of Phaeoacremonium minimum UCRPA7 may provide valuable insights into the understanding and management of grapevine trunk diseases caused by this fungal species.
